hints_html: Remember to think of y as being fixed (that is, constant) when you take a partial derivative with respect to x.
hints_latex:
Remember to think of \emph{y} as being fixed (that is, constant) when
you take a partial derivative with respect to \emph{x}.
hints_raw: Remember to think of ''y'' as being fixed (that is, constant) when you take a partial derivative with respect to ''x''.
question: 1 (a)
sols_html:
The first step is straightforward partial differentiation. Take the derivative of \(f\) with respect to \(x\), treating \(y\) as a relative constant (use the chain rule):

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} = \left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x}((1 - x)y)\right)e^{(1 - x)y} = -ye^{(1 - x)y}.\end{aligned}\]

Now we just substitute \((x,y) = (2,1)\):

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}(2,1) &= -1e^{(1 - 2)1} \\ &= -e^{-1}\end{aligned}\]
statement_html: Compute \(\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}(2,1)\) if \(\displaystyle f(x,y) = e^{(1 - x)y}\).
statement_latex:
Compute $\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}(2,1)$ if
$\displaystyle f(x,y) = e^{(1 - x)y}$.
statement_raw: Compute <math>\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}(2,1)</math> if <math>\displaystyle f(x,y) = e^{(1 - x)y}</math>.
